items.title: Source Code: My Beginnings by Bill Gates review – refreshingly frank
items.summary:
- Bill Gates reflects on his early life and career in the first volume of his memoir trilogy, covering from 1955 to the founding of Microsoft in 1975.
- Gates describes his childhood in Seattle, early computer experiences, and his partnership with Paul Allen.
- The book emphasizes Gates's gratitude for mentors, acknowledges his upbringing privileges, and explores personal losses, including a friend's death in a mountaineering accident.

items.title: New technology could make fridges cheaper and more eco-friendly
items.summary:
- A report indicates new technology could reduce refrigerator costs and enhance eco-friendliness.
- Refrigerators accounted for about 4% of global electricity consumption in 2019, highlighting the significance of energy-saving innovations.
- Research from Huazhong University shows that thermogalvanic technology offers a sustainable alternative to traditional refrigeration cooling methods.
- The technology could enable widespread carbon neutrality if adopted broadly, as stated by senior author Jiangjiang Duan.
- Thermogalvanic cells generate electricity using heat from reversible chemical reactions, representing potential for various applications, including wearable devices.
- Optimizations in chemical use improved cooling power of hydrogalvanic cells by 70%.
- Refrigerators contribute significantly to greenhouse gases, with substantial emissions stemming from their electricity use and gas leakages.
- Future research aims to optimize designs and expand commercial applications of thermogalvanic technology.

items.title: An Update on Our Family review – these influencers’ murky tale makes you long to end the internet
items.summary:
- The documentary follows the Stauffer family, a former successful family vlogging couple, exploring the implications of their online persona and monetizing their family experiences.
- The narrative intensifies when they adopt Huxley, a boy with special needs from China, and later remove him from their videos, leading to public outrage and conspiracy theories.
- The film raises ethical questions about filming children without consent, the nature of parasocial relationships, and the motives behind sharing personal lives online.

items.title: Apple to report earnings for first quarter of 2025
items.summary:
- Apple will report earnings for Q1 2025 after markets close on Thursday.
- Analysts estimate quarterly revenue at $124.39 billion, a 4% year-over-year growth, with earnings per share at $2.35.
- Investors are focused on Apple's developments in artificial intelligence, which have progressed slowly and received mixed reviews, especially for the AI-powered product launched in October.
- The tech sector has faced challenges, with many stocks tumbling after a Chinese AI company's app topped the App Store, causing significant losses in market value.
- Despite market fluctuations, Apple's stock remained stable earlier in the week, though its prices have fallen about 8% due to decreasing phone sales in China.
- Apple’s AI has faced issues, including inaccuracies in notifications, leading to complaints from the BBC regarding misinformation generated by the tech.

items.title: Get ahead of the tech curve: aim for Hangzhou, not Silicon Valley | Brief letters
items.author: John Lowery, Dr Jonathan J Ross, Laura Ashton, Emma Tait, Dr Richard O’Brien, Neil Hanson
items.summary:
- Rachel Reeves proposes creating "Europe’s Silicon Valley," but the author suggests looking towards Hangzhou instead.
- Hangzhou is home to DeepSeek, which significantly impacted US tech stock values.
- The article contains letters addressing various topics including a vertebra found online and experiences starting holidays at airport bars.

items.title: SoftBank ‘in talks’ to invest up to $25bn in OpenAI
items.summary:
- SoftBank is in discussions to invest between $15bn and $25bn in OpenAI, potentially becoming its largest financial backer.
- The investment follows a previous funding round that valued OpenAI at $157bn, which included support from Microsoft.
- SoftBank and OpenAI recently partnered with Oracle to launch Stargate, a large AI infrastructure project, with an initial investment goal of $100bn.
- Claims have emerged regarding the financial capacity of Stargate's backers, prompting a response from OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman.

items.title: Meta agrees to pay Trump $25m for suspending accounts over Capitol riots
items.summary:
- Meta has settled a lawsuit with Donald Trump for $25 million over the suspension of his accounts after the January 6 Capitol riot.
- $22 million of the settlement will fund Trump’s presidential library, while the rest covers legal fees and other plaintiffs.
- Zuckerberg’s decision to suspend Trump’s accounts was due to perceived risks during civil unrest; Trump has since reinstated on Facebook and Instagram after a two-year suspension.

items.title: Microsoft to report fourth-quarter earnings amid uproar over DeepSeek’s AI
items.summary:
- Microsoft is set to report its second-quarter earnings for fiscal year 2025 on Wednesday, facing scrutiny over AI spending amid the DeepSeek controversy.
- Wall Street anticipates $3.11 earnings per share and $68.9bn in revenue, an increase from the previous year’s $2.93 a share and $62bn.
- The $600bn drop in Nvidia's market capitalization highlights the impacts of DeepSeek's AI model achieving similar results to US firms at lower costs.
- Microsoft and OpenAI are probing whether DeepSeek-linked groups accessed OpenAI’s data improperly.
- David Sacks of the White House suggested DeepSeek may have stolen US intellectual property related to AI.
- Microsoft retains a “right of first refusal” with OpenAI following changes in their partnership status.

items.title: Tesla to report fourth-quarter earnings amid declining car delivery numbers
items.summary:
- Tesla will report earnings for Q4 2024 on Wednesday, with analysts predicting $0.62 EPS and $27.22 billion in revenue.
- The company has faced a decline in annual vehicle deliveries for the first time, struggling against cheaper competitors like BYD.
- European subsidies for electric cars are decreasing, and Tesla's vehicle registrations in Europe fell 24% in October.
- The recently released Cybertruck has not compensated for declining demand for older models, and Tesla's autonomous driving software is under federal investigation.

items.title: DeepSeek blocked from some app stores in Italy amid questions on data use
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI platform, is blocked from some app stores in Italy due to data handling concerns.
- Italian and Irish regulators are demanding answers about citizens’ data usage by DeepSeek.
- The app was reportedly removed from Apple and Google stores in Italy, with users receiving unavailability messages.
- The Italian regulator, Garante, is investigating compliance with GDPR regulations and has given DeepSeek 20 days to respond.
- DeepSeek claims to store personal information on secure servers in China and to use data to comply with legal obligations.
- The UK government is monitoring potential national security threats from DeepSeek.
- OpenAI is investigating allegations that DeepSeek may have used its AI models improperly.

items.title: Meta to report fourth-quarter earnings amid DeepSeek mania and ballooning AI investments
items.summary:
- Meta's earnings report for Q4 2024 is due after US stock markets close on Wednesday.
- Mark Zuckerberg plans to invest $60-$65 billion in AI infrastructure for 2025, up from $50 billion previously projected.
- Meta is facing competition from new AI player DeepSeek, prompting an increase in AI development efforts.
- The company launched a more personalized AI assistant and claims its AI is the most used virtual assistant.
- Analysts anticipate a defensive stance during the earnings call, focusing on concerns about eliminating third-party fact-checking programs.
- Meta will also address workforce reductions, targeting low performers with a 5% staff cut.
- Reports indicate Reality Labs achieved significant growth in 2024, with a 40% increase in sales and users, alongside a leadership shake-up expected.

items.title: What video game ephemera tell us about ourselves
items.summary:
- The Video Game History Foundation is sharing a digital archive of about 1,500 games magazines starting January 30.
- The National Videogame Museum focuses on collecting materials that reflect individual gaming experiences and stories behind collections.
- The cultural relevance of video game materials is growing as institutions begin to collect these artifacts, with 87% of classic video games considered critically endangered.
- Personal experiences with gaming can hold significant emotional value, as reflected in the author’s nostalgic recollections of their gaming collection and memories associated with it.

items.title: What International AI Safety report says on jobs, climate, cyberwar and more
items.summary:
- The International AI Safety report highlights significant challenges posed by rapidly advancing AI technologies.
- The report warns of profound job impacts due to capable AI agents, with potential for new jobs but also significant job losses in advanced economies.
- AI's energy consumption contributes to 1% of greenhouse gas emissions, with increasing demands from datacentres, raising environmental concerns.
- Concerns over loss of control of powerful AI systems are noted, with varying opinions on the likelihood of negative outcomes.
- AI models could create advanced bioweapons, but there are uncertainties about their use by untrained individuals.
- Cybersecurity threats from AI include autonomous bots finding software vulnerabilities, but attacks cannot currently be carried out independently.
- The report discusses the malicious use of deepfakes, noting a lack of data to fully measure the impact and challenges in addressing them.

items.title: Chinese firms ‘distilling’ US AI models to create rival products, warns OpenAI
items.summary:
- OpenAI warns that Chinese startups are using its technology to develop competing products, particularly a chatbot by DeepSeek.
- DeepSeek’s chatbot launch caused a market drop, wiping $1 trillion from AI-linked US tech stocks due to its claims of lower operational costs.
- OpenAI, alongside Microsoft, is investigating unauthorized use of its technology through 'distillation'.
- OpenAI’s CEO expressed initial admiration for DeepSeek but later highlighted evidence of potential intellectual property theft.
- US government agencies, including the Navy, are assessing the national security implications of DeepSeek's AI technology.

items.title: DeepSeek advances could heighten safety risk, says ‘godfather’ of AI
items.author: Yoshua Bengio
items.summary:
- A report by AI experts warns that systems like DeepSeek could increase safety risks in AI.
- Yoshua Bengio highlights concerns over AI advancements by the Chinese startup DeepSeek, suggesting competition may detract from safety priorities.
- The International AI Safety report, led by Bengio, includes input from 96 experts and outlines risks such as potential misuse in cyber attacks and deepfakes.
- AI systems now capable of generating harmful instructions autonomously, although executing attacks remains a challenge.
- The report notes increased risks from both open-source and closed-source AI models, emphasizing the need for regulatory intervention.

items.title: Rise and shine with the seven best sunrise alarm clocks, tried and tested
items.summary:
- Sunrise alarm clocks help align waking with the natural circadian rhythm, enhancing health and mood.
- Key models tested include Lumie Bodyclock Spark 100, Philips SmartSleep, and Beurer Wake-Up Light WL50.
- Models certified for light therapy specifically target conditions like Seasonal Affective Disorder.
- The Lumie Bodyclock Spark 100 is praised for its realistic sunrise simulation and design.
- Philips SmartSleep offers easy setup and various audio options but is on the pricier side.
- The Beurer WL50 is highlighted as ideal for couples, catering to dual wake-up needs.

items.title: ‘Headed for technofascism’: the rightwing roots of Silicon Valley
items.summary:
- The article explores the historical rightwing roots of Silicon Valley, highlighting concerns from the 1990s about a potential "technofascism" emerging within the tech industry.
- It focuses on George Gilder, a key figure in Silicon Valley's reactionary movement, who promoted a vision of entrepreneurship tied to traditional gender roles and a critique of the welfare state.
- The narrative discusses media portrayal of tech entrepreneurs like Steve Jobs and Marc Andreessen as embodiments of American masculinity and economic progress, while ignoring the implications of gender and political conservatism in Silicon Valley's culture.

items.title: An easy to read and interpret title for the article as a string.
items.author: Andrew Przybylski
items.summary:
- Andrew Przybylski, an Oxford University professor, argues that fears over 'brain rot' from technology are unfounded.
- Oxford University Press declared 'brain rot' as the word of the year, highlighting concerns about online content.
- Studies show no evidence linking screen time with negative cognitive effects in children.
- Przybylski emphasizes that living is inherently risky, and children must learn to navigate these risks responsibly.
- Historical parallels drawn between past media consumption and current digital habits.
- Technologies can also foster community and connection, enhancing overall wellbeing.
- The narrative that digital tech is depleting IQ lacks solid scientific backing and relies on anecdotal evidence.

items.title: Threat of cyber-attacks on Whitehall ‘is severe and advancing quickly’, NAO says
items.summary:
- The National Audit Office (NAO) warns of a severe risk of cyber-attacks on UK government departments, with critical IT systems vulnerable.
- An assessment found 58 critical IT systems had significant gaps in cyber-resilience; the government lacks knowledge on 228 legacy systems' vulnerabilities.
- Recent attacks include one on the British Library by a ransomware gang and another affecting NHS services, leading to significant disruptions.
- Challenges include poor coordination, staffing shortages, and reliance on outdated IT systems, with the government not meeting its cyber-defense goals by 2025.
- GCHQ highlighted a widening gap between increasing cyber threats and UK defense capabilities, naming key adversaries like China and Russia.

items.title: Chinese AI chatbot DeepSeek censors itself in realtime, users report
items.summary:
- Users report that DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, censors itself in real time while responding to queries.
- The chatbot begins by generating thoughtful responses but abruptly removes sensitive content, reflecting self-censorship under Chinese governance.
- A user experienced this firsthand while discussing free speech in China, noting that the chatbot quickly shifted from insightful commentary to refusing to engage with the topic.

items.title: What will Washington do about Chinese startup DeepSeek and its AI chatbot?
items.summary:
- The White House is investigating national security concerns surrounding DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup.
- DeepSeek’s AI assistant app is gaining popularity in the US and UK, recently recovering from a cyberattack that limited registrations.
- The tech sector's stock market saw a decline of $1 trillion in reaction to DeepSeek’s rise, significantly affecting Nvidia’s market cap.
- DeepSeek’s app reportedly censors sensitive political topics, raising concerns about user data privacy potentially being shared with the Chinese government.
- Washington is reconsidering its approach to Chinese tech apps amid ongoing TikTok negotiations, with Trump emphasizing the need for US competitiveness.
- Sam Altman of OpenAI acknowledged DeepSeek’s R1 model as impressive, indicating a shift in the perception of AI innovation globally.

items.title: Former OpenAI safety researcher brands pace of AI development ‘terrifying’
items.author: Steven Adler
items.summary:
- Steven Adler, a former safety researcher at [OpenAI](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/openai), expresses concern about the rapid pace of AI development, calling it a "very risky gamble."
- Adler fears the race for artificial general intelligence (AGI) could have catastrophic consequences, highlighting doubts about the future of humanity.
- He notes that no research lab currently has a solution for AI alignment, raising alarms about the industry’s speed compromising safety regulations.

items.title: Tech billionaires lost almost $100bn in stock market selloff sparked by DeepSeek
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's AI challenge caused a $600bn loss in Nvidia's market value, leading to a 3% drop in Nasdaq.  
- Nvidia's stock plunge resulted in CEO Jensen Huang losing $20.7bn, dropping from 10th to 17th in global wealth rankings.  
- Oracle's Larry Ellison lost $27.6bn, falling from third to fifth wealthiest.  
- Total losses among tech billionaires reached $94bn, contributing to the $108bn loss reported.  
- Upcoming earnings reports from Meta, Microsoft, Tesla, and Apple may address AI spending concerns.  
- Analysts suggest selloff may be an overreaction; demand for top AI hardware is expected to persist.

items.title: The best window vacs for clearing condensation: seven expert picks for streak-free shine
items.summary:
- Window vacuums, unlike regular vacuum cleaners, are designed to suck up water rather than dirt.
- Useful for clearing condensation, damp problems, and drying windows after washing.
- Best overall pick is the Kärcher WV2, praised for its balance of size and usability.
- Best budget option is Tower TWV10, offering good performance at a low price point.
- Kärcher WV1 is ideal for smaller living spaces with a 25cm suction nozzle.
- Each model tested for battery life, suction efficiency, and ability to leave surfaces dry without streaks.
- Emphasis on real-world usage and thorough testing methods including airflow measurement and practical application.

items.title: Experts urge caution over use of Chinese AI DeepSeek
items.summary:
- Experts express concerns over the Chinese AI platform DeepSeek regarding misinformation and data exploitation by the state.
- DeepSeek, a low-cost AI, caused a $1 trillion drop in the US tech stock index and became the most downloaded app in the UK and US shortly after release.
- Professors warn against inputting sensitive data, citing potential data sharing with the Chinese government.
- The open-source platform has the potential to drive innovation but raises concerns about compliance with Chinese government regulations.
- Users testing DeepSeek found it avoids discussing sensitive topics like the Tiananmen Square incident, reflecting biases in the AI's training data.

items.title: How do you solve a problem like DeepSeek?
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup, has released an open-sourced model named R1 that operates with significantly lower computing power and cost than competitors like ChatGPT.
- The model’s efficiency raises concerns about the US's dominance in AI and its trade embargoes against China, given DeepSeek secured around 50,000 GPUs within regulatory constraints.
- DeepSeek's success has led to market impacts, including Nvidia's stock decline, as the company requires fewer resources to achieve comparable outcomes.
- R1's rise in app stores prompts questions regarding censorship and US regulations, especially in light of existing tensions over Chinese technology influence.

items.title: Google Maps will rename Gulf of Mexico as Gulf of America in US
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Google will change Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America on Google Maps in the US following a Trump executive order.
- The name will remain Gulf of Mexico in Mexico, and users outside both countries will see both names on Google Maps.
- Denali will be reverted to Mount McKinley in the US as part of the same executive order.
- The changes align with Trump's campaign promise and will be implemented once updated in the US government’s geographic names information system.
- Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum humorously suggested renaming North America to "América Mexicana" in response to the changes.

items.title: Scans for the memories: why old games magazines are a vital source of cultural history – and nostalgia
items.summary:
- The Video Game History Foundation will open its digital archive of out-of-print games magazines on January 30.
- Current collection includes 1,500 issues, and the archive will be searchable by keywords.
- Old gaming magazines offer cultural insights and document the industry's evolution and socio-cultural narratives.

items.title: Trump says China’s DeepSeek AI chatbot is a ‘wake-up call’
items.summary:
- Donald Trump described the launch of China’s DeepSeek AI chatbot as a "wake-up call" for US tech firms in the AI race.
- DeepSeek's R1 model chatbot was built at a fraction of the cost of competitors like OpenAI’s ChatGPT.
- The launch wiped $1 trillion from the US tech index, including a $600 billion loss for Nvidia, marking the biggest single-day fall in US stock market history.
- Trump mentioned DeepSeek's performance is comparable to existing models but uses far fewer resources, urging US industries to compete more aggressively.
- DeepSeek's assistant surpassed ChatGPT in downloads from Apple's app store on the launch day.
- Marc Andreessen likened the launch to a pivotal moment in the US-USSR space race, calling it AI's "Sputnik moment".

items.title: How ChatGPT, Gemini and DeepSeek deal with Tiananmen Square and Taiwan questions – video
items.summary:
- A new Chinese AI competes with US tech at a lower cost and is gaining popularity internationally.
- The app reportedly censors responses to sensitive topics related to China and its government.
- An article discusses the performance of the AI, particularly its limitations when addressing questions about Tiananmen Square and Taiwan.

items.title: My Gruelling Week of Calling Gen Z Friends Rather Than Texting
items.summary:
- The author conducted an experiment of calling friends instead of texting for a week.  
- A Uswitch survey revealed 61% of Gen Z prefer texting over calling, with 23% rarely answering calls.  
- There’s increasing phone call anxiety, with a Nottingham college offering sessions for ‘telephobia’.  
- Professor Duncan Brumby suggests society has moved towards asynchronous communication, as phone calls are often associated with negative outcomes.  
- The experiment made the author anxious, leading to missed calls and awkward situations.  
- The realization that texting lacks the intimacy found in phone conversations was a highlight of the week.  
- By calling various friends, the author found moments of connection that texting often overlooked.

items.title: Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok, Trump claims
items.summary:
- Donald Trump claims Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok and anticipates a bidding war.
- Trump confirmed interest in TikTok, stating there is 'great interest' in the app.  
- The talks mark the second attempt for Microsoft to acquire TikTok, after previous discussions in 2020 collapsed.
- TikTok, with approximately 170 million US users, was briefly taken offline ahead of a law requiring its Chinese owner to sell or face a ban.
- Trump signed an executive order delaying law enforcement on TikTok by 75 days after taking office.
- AI startup Perplexity AI has proposed a merger with TikTok, potentially involving government shares in the new company.

items.title: We tried out DeepSeek. It works well, until we asked it about Tiananmen Square and Taiwan
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a new chatbot from China, quickly became popular, surpassing ChatGPT in the US and UK app stores.
- It censors sensitive topics like Tiananmen Square and political events, offering evasive responses instead.
- Users found ways to bypass censorship by phrasing questions differently, like using special characters.
- DeepSeek's responses about Taiwan aligned with Chinese government views, denying its independence.
- In contrast, ChatGPT and Gemini provided nuanced replies about Taiwan's status and other political topics.

items.title: Meta’s content moderation changes ‘hugely concerning’, says Molly Rose Foundation
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg's changes to Meta's content moderation policies may lead to an increase in harmful content, possibly reminiscent of the circumstances surrounding Molly Russell's death.
- The Molly Rose Foundation is urging the UK’s Ofcom to strengthen regulations on social media platforms to protect youth from harmful content related to suicide and self-harm.
- Meta has replaced fact-checkers with a “community notes” system that allows users to assess truthfulness, which has raised concerns about the normalization of harmful behavior in online content.
- Andy Burrows, chief executive of the Molly Rose Foundation, expressed alarm over Meta's safety measure rollbacks, urging regulatory intervention to protect children.
- Ofcom has a draft safety code that requires tech firms to mitigate the recommendations of harmful content and enforce age checks, with final codes expected by April.

items.title: DeepSeek hit with ‘large-scale’ cyber-attack after AI chatbot tops app stores
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's AI assistant app faced a cyber-attack on Monday, prompting temporary registration limits.
- The attack followed the app's rise to the top of Apple’s App Store and high rankings in Google’s Play Store.
- DeepSeek began investigating the issue late Monday night and confirmed a ‘large-scale malicious attack’.
- Registrations are now open again, with a statement saying, 'DeepSeek-R1 is now live'.
- The app's success has impacted technology stocks, notably with Nvidia losing 13.6%, equating to $500bn in market cap.
- Investors view DeepSeek’s rapid development of an AI assistant as potentially threatening US market dominance.

items.title: Tesla takes EU to court over tariffs on EVs made in China
items.author: Elon Musk
items.summary:
- Tesla has filed a complaint against the European Commission over tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.
- The EU decided to impose tariffs on imports of Chinese electric cars due to allegations of unfair state subsidies by the Chinese government.
- The tariffs were approved in October 2024 and are set at 7.8% for Tesla, compared to as high as 35.3% for competitors.
- The legal case comes as Elon Musk faces scrutiny for his ties to Donald Trump and criticisms of the EU.
- Several German carmakers have also criticized the tariffs and are challenging them in court.
- The EU's decision followed a study on subsidies including free land and tax exemptions given to Chinese manufacturers.

items.title: A wholesome escape from the housing crisis: the Facebook group dedicated to retro Australian homes
items.summary:
- Members of the Facebook group 'Retro Houses for Sale Australia' share a common dislike for white paint renovations on mid-century homes.
- The group serves as a space to showcase and discuss retro homes from the 50s, 60s, and 70s currently for sale, fostering a shared appreciation for preserved properties.
- There is a growing concern about the decline of retro homes in Australia, as many are replaced with newer constructions, leading to a loss of character and history.

items.title: Global tech shares fall as China AI chatbot DeepSeek spooks investors
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, has emerged as a competitor to OpenAI’s ChatGPT, causing global tech stocks to decline.
- The Nasdaq index opened lower, with Nvidia losing over $400bn in value, marking the largest fall in US stock market history.
- DeepSeek’s R1 model reportedly outperforms OpenAI’s models using fewer chips, raising questions about US investments in AI technology.

items.title: People in the US: share your experience of using TikTok
items.summary:
- US TikTok users prepare for a ban set for 19 January, but an executive order by Donald Trump grants a 75-day extension.
- TikTok is currently unavailable in app stores for new downloads, but users with the app can still use it.
- The article invites US users to share their experiences regarding the impact of the ban on their work and app usage, including alternative apps they might be using.

items.title: ‘TikTok could malfunction’: app’s future in limbo as it remains off US app stores
items.summary:
- TikTok is currently absent from Apple and Google's app stores in the US, despite being back operationally after a temporary shutdown on January 18.
- A White House executive order has allowed TikTok to operate while the enforcement of a law requiring its sale is suspended for 75 days.
- Apple and Google remain cautious, fearing potential legal consequences for hosting the app, despite assurances from the government.
- Larry Ellison of Oracle has been suggested as a potential buyer for TikTok, further complicating its future as Trump hints at possible deals.
- The app's deletion from US stores prevents users from reinstalling it, leading to potential malfunctions as updates cannot be provided.

items.title: The 15 best Xbox Series S/X games to play in 2025
items.summary:
- Focus on 15 diverse and notable games for Xbox Series S/X in 2025.
- Highlights include titles such as [Alan Wake 2](https://www.theguardian.com/games/2023/oct/26/alan-wake-2-review-playstation-5-xbox-series-xs-pc-remedy-entertainmentepic-games-27-october) and [Baldur’s Gate 3](https://www.theguardian.com/games/2023/aug/09/baldurs-gate-3-review-pc-mac-ps5-larian).
- Emphasis on genres ranging from horror to RPG, showcasing creative gameplay and narratives.

items.title: ‘Serious concerns’ about DWP’s use of AI to read correspondence from benefit claimants
items.summary:
- The DWP receives 25,000 letters and emails daily from over 20 million benefit claimants in the UK.
- They are using an AI named "white mail" to prioritize urgent cases, reducing human processing time from weeks to a day.
- Serious concerns have been raised regarding the transparency and handling of sensitive personal data by the AI.
- Critics argue that benefit claimants are not informed about the AI's use, raising ethical implications.
- There are calls for more transparency, performance data, audits, and safeguards to protect vulnerable claimants.

items.title: AI prototypes for UK welfare system dropped as officials lament ‘false starts’
items.summary:
- Ministers have canceled at least six AI prototypes meant for the welfare system, indicating challenges in implementing government efficiency.
- AI pilots aimed to enhance jobcentre services and accelerate payments for disabilities have been scrapped following internal assessments.
- Department for Work and Pensions previously reported successful tests of generative AI concepts, but faced friction in scaling and reliability of technology.
- Government officials state the learning from dropped projects will inform future implementations of AI in public services.
- There are ongoing discussions about transparency regarding AI usage in the welfare system, with no data disclosed on the algorithm transparency register.

items.title: Gov.uk app could lead to ‘mandatory ID scheme’, claim privacy groups
items.summary:
- A new gov.uk app aims to hold driving licenses, passports, and benefits documents digitally.
- Privacy groups warn it could launch a mandatory ID scheme despite claims from the government that participation will remain voluntary.
- The app utilizes biometric security, including facial scans, and is inspired by similar technologies in countries like Poland and Estonia.
- Concerns raised over the potential for a national identity database and privacy implications.
- The app is set to be available in June, with the wallet following to securely save digital documents.

items.title: How the roots of the ‘PayPal mafia’ extend to apartheid South Africa
items.summary:
- Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, part of the 'PayPal mafia', have roots in apartheid-era South Africa.
- Musk’s recent endorsement of far-right conspiracy theories has raised concerns about his background in a racially repressive environment.
- Other prominent members of the 'PayPal mafia' include David Sacks and Roelof Botha, who also have ties to South African apartheid.
- Thiel has been reported to have defended apartheid during his education and has expressed far-right views in the US.
- The article explores how their formative years in apartheid South Africa may have shaped their political ideologies today.

items.title: Convenient or intrusive? How Poland has embraced digital ID cards
items.summary:
- Poland has embraced digital identity cards and a mobile app called mObywatel, used by 8 million users.
- Users verify their identity through electronic banking or a physical ID card to access services.
- The app allows users to check driving licence points, vehicle history, local air quality, and polling stations.
- EU's eIDAS 2.0 regulation will enable cross-border digital ID verification by 2026 or 2027.
- Future features may include accident reporting to insurers and online age verification.
- Privacy concerns are raised regarding the potential for intrusive data use, but improvements in data control are suggested.

items.title: Germany too focused on past guilt, Elon Musk tells AfD event – video
items.summary:
- Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk spoke at a campaign event for the far-right Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) party in Halle, eastern Germany.
- Musk claimed Germany is overly focused on past guilt and suggested that the AfD represents the best hope for the country.
- The event received media attention as it highlighted Musk's controversial support for the AfD party.

items.title: Jewish non-profit chief says Musk will spur violence with his ‘Nazi salute’
‘Our job is to be truthful not neutral’: Christiane Amanpour on Trump, tech and fighting for the truth
items.summary:
- Christiane Amanpour reflects on her career in journalism spanning over 40 years.
- After a holiday in South Africa, she anticipates the challenges ahead, particularly with Trump's second presidency.
- Amanpour emphasizes the importance of being "truthful, not neutral" in journalism.
- She expresses concern over the impact of tech figures like Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg on media integrity.
- Amanpour's early experiences in Iran during the 1979 revolution shaped her understanding of courage and conflict.
- Discusses ongoing struggles faced by women in Iran and women’s resistance under the Taliban in Afghanistan.

items.title: Elon Musk makes surprise appearance at AfD event in eastern Germany
items.summary:
- Elon Musk appeared at AfD event in Halle, eastern Germany, supporting the far-right party for the second time in weeks.
- He spoke to an audience of 4,500, advocating for the preservation of German culture and values.
- Musk commented on Germany’s Nazi past, suggesting excessive focus on historical guilt should be moved beyond.
- He criticized the German government's stance on freedom of speech regarding extreme-right views and praised the AfD as a hopeful future for Germany.
- Around 100,000 anti-far-right protesters gathered in Berlin, with additional demonstrations in Cologne.
